column1: Richard Michael "Mike" Mullane (born September 10, 1945) is a retired USAF officer and a former NASA astronaut, flying on three Space Shuttle missions.
Mullane was born in Wichita Falls, Texas, but considers Albuquerque, New Mexico, to be his hometown.
He was a Second Class Scout in the Boy Scouts of America.
He is a member of the Air Force Association.
Mullane, an Air Force Colonel, was graduated from West Point in 1967.
He completed 134 combat missions as an RF-4C weapon system operator while stationed at Tan Son Nhut Air Base, Vietnam, from January to November 1969.
He subsequently served a 4-year tour of duty, in England.
Selected by NASA in January 1978, Mullane became an astronaut in August 1979.

column2: This was the maiden flight of the Orbiter Discovery.

column1: STS 41-D completed 96 orbits of the Earth in 145 hours before landing at Edwards Air Force Base, California, on September 5, 1984.
After the Shuttle returned to service, he flew aboard the Orbiter Atlantis, on STS-27, which launched from Kennedy Space Center, Florida, on December 2, 1988.
The mission carried a Department of Defense (DOD) payload, as well as a number of secondary payloads.

column2: This mission carried DOD payloads and a number of secondary payloads.

column1: After 72 orbits of the earth, the STS-36 mission concluded with a lakebed landing at Edwards Air Force Base, California, on March 4, 1990.
With the completion of his third flight, Mullane logged a total of 356 hours in space.
He retired from NASA and the Air Force in 1990.
Mullane appeared on the U.S. television show The Daily Show with Jon Stewart on Monday, February 13, 2006 to promote his book Riding Rockets.
